title: What's new?
content:
Earlier this year I wrote an article for Graphic Exchange, \<a href=" [http://www.shinntype.com/Stories/Uniformity.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141128/http:/www.shinntype.com/Stories/Uniformity.pdf)"\>The Face of Uniformity,\</a\> in which I criticized the widespread use of old sans-serif typefaces.   
   
As a follow-up, in my next article I will be discussing original, contemporary typefaces.   
   
That doesn't exclude designs in traditional genres, although I would be more inclined to include Frank Heine's Dalliance than his Tribute.   
   
Any suggestions? (Type designers, feel free to mention your own work.)
author: scoffer

comments.content:
I would focus on Eastern Europe and South America.   
And I would immodestly suggest Patria too... It's gonna be the new gray. :-)

Spot on Nick.   
   
Loved the article. My feelings exactly.

Yes, great article - very informative, and a great close.   
You should try to get it published widely.   
   
\>\> "The look of late 60s typography was very,   
\>\> very tight, and this way of setting has   
\>\> become intimately associated with Helvetica.   
   
Not least because Helvetica's default spacing is way too tight (for good readability)!   
   
Doyald Young in fact offers a very interesting -if also somewhat esoteric- explanation for the greater success of Helvetica over Univers: the latter is -or actually seemed- too loose.
